questions.text: Philtrum develops from fusion of-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

2 Medial nasal process

In humans, the philtrum is formed where the nasomedial (or medial nasal) and maxillary processes meet during embryonic development (colloquially known as Hulse lines).
When these processes fail to fuse fully in humans, a cleft lip (sometimes called a "hare lip") can result.
A flattened or smooth philtrum can be a symptom of Fetal alcohol syndrome or Prader-Willi syndrome.

questions.text: Identify true statement regarding teriparatide
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Teriparatide [hPTH(1–34)] and abaloparatide [PTHrP(1–34)] are the only anabolic agents currently available that increase new bone formation. teriparatide increases BMD and reduces the risk of vertebral and nonvertebral fractures. Adverse effects include hypercalcemia (the incidence with abaloparatide. is lower than observed with teriparatide, exacerbation of nephrolithiasis, and elevation of serum uric acid levels. Development of osteosarcoma has been a serious concern in patients treated with teriparatide. Teriparatide is administered by once-daily subcutaneous injection of 20 μg into the thigh or abdomen. use should be limited to no more than 2 years and avoided in patients who are at increased baseline risk for osteosarcoma

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy whose family recently immigrated from Bangladesh is brought to the pediatric OPD due to sore throat and fever. Physical examination shows mild tonsillar erythema with exudates. A sample from the exudates is obtained. On microscopic evaluation, there are clumped, gram positive bacteria with polar granules that stain deeply with aniline dyes. Which of the following best explains the pathogenicity of the organism most likely responsible for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

It’s a case of diphtheria caused by Corynebacterium diphtheriae.
It colonizes in respiratory tract & secrete diphtheria toxin, the primary virulence factor
Diphtheria toxin is an AB exotoxin that inhibits protein synthesis by ADP-ribosylation of EF-2
Toxin acts locally, causing respiratory cell necrosis with formation of fibrinous, coagulative exudates.

questions.text: A 20-year-old woman comes to the clinic with a one-week history of painful swelling in her right axilla as shown in the image that was preceded by malaise, headaches, and night sweats. Temperature is 37.80 C , blood pressure is 126/78 mm Hg, and pulse is 88/min. Physical examination shows enlarged and tender epitrochlear and axillary lymph nodes on the right side. Histopathologic examination of a lymph node shows scattered necrotizing granulomas and stellate microabscesses containing pleomorphic, gram-negative coccobacilli. Which of the following is the most likely route of transmission of this patient's infection?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

This patient with tender axillary and epitrochlear lymphadenopathy has histopathologic findings consistent with cat-scratch disease, caused by Bartonella henselae infection. 
B henselae is a fastidious, gram-negative coccobacillus that is transmitted to humans {typically children and young adults) through a scratch or bite from an infected cat.
Treatment : Azithromycin or Doxycycline.

questions.text: A 39-year-old paraplegic man with an indwelling bladder catheter comes to the emergency department complaining of 24 hours of rigors, nausea, and vomiting. His temperature is 38.90 C. Physical examination shows suprapubic and costovertebral angle tenderness. Urinalysis shows 3+ leukocyte esterase and numerous white blood cells. Urine and blood cultures grow non-lactose-fermenting Gram-negative rods. Colonies in nutrient agar shown in the image. Choose correct selective medium for this pathogen.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Patients with indwelling bladder catheters are at increased risk for urinary tract infections (UTIs) caused by both typical (eg, Escherichia coli, Klebsiella pneumoniae , Staphylococcus saprophyticus, Proteus mirabilis ) and opportunistic (eg, Pseudomonas, Enterococcus, other Staphylococci, fungal) organisms. 
Non lactose fermenter with diffusible pigment production suggestive of Pseudomonas aeruginosa.
Selective medium is cetrimide agar.

questions.text: A 59-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department with fever, skin flushing, and an altered level of consciousness. Blood pressure is 50/20 mm Hg and pulse is 120/min despite receiving intravenous fluids. Blood cultures are positive for Escherichia coli. Which of the following bacterial components is most directly responsible for this patient's current condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

This patient with positive Escherichia coli blood cultures has altered mental status, hypotension, and tachycardia, findings consistent with septic shock.
Pathogenesis of sepsis and septic shock caused by gram-negative bacteria (eg, E coii ) involves the release of bacterial endotoxins into the bloodstream, which induce a massive release of inflammatory cytokines. 
The most potent endotoxin of gram-negative bacteria is lipopolysaccharide (LPS), a heat-stable component in the outer membrane that is released with destruction of the bacterial cell wall or during cell division.
The major virulence component of LPS is lipid A , which is located on the inner portion of the molecule and provides an anchor into the cell membrane.

questions.text: A PLHIV came with pain in the hip region. Aspiration stained with Giemsa staining shows multiple monocytes and macrophages with yeast like organism of 4-6 µm size in the cytoplasm of cells. The organism might be:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Case of osteomyelitis in HIV infected patient, with intracellular yeast of 4-6 µm size - most likely diagnosis is histoplasmosis. 
Histopathological staining of specimens reveals tiny oval yeast cells (2–4 µm size) with narrow based budding within the macrophages and underlying granulomatous response.
Histoplasma is a dimorphic fungus: At 25°C: Produces white mycelial colonies that consist of two types of conidia: Thick tuberculate macroconidia (characteristic) and thin microconidia
At 37°C: It gets converted into yeast form (creamy white colonies) in special Kelley’s media

questions.text: A 20-year-old man who is a biology major presents to his physician for a simple check-up. He is informed that he hasn't received a hepatitis B vaccine. When the first injection is applied, the medical professional informs him that he will need to come back 2 more times on assigned days, since the vaccine is given in 3 doses. Which of the following antibodies is the physician trying to increase in the college student as a result of the first vaccination?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

The hepatitis B vaccine is a subunit vaccine comprised of the hepatitis B surface antigen that is applied in 3 doses. 
When the first dose is given. patients will produce immunoglobulin M (lgM), and only a small number of these will undergo isotype switching to immunoglobulin G [IgG]. 
After patients receive a second and third dose, it causes a much higher, more protective concentration of lgG to be produced and sustained within the body.
It is also important to note that the dose of antigen present in the first shot is much higher than in the second and third ones since the immune system has a higher affinity to the antigen on a second and third encounter.

questions.text: A study is being done to follow up 30,000 people for 30 years; 1200 cases developed and for every case which developed 1:1 control was allotted at the same time from those who were non diseased. The type of study design is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

NCC Explanation Advanced Cohort Study:

Case Control Studies Based in A defined Cohort Properties

• Predominantly a type of cohort study (due to a forward direction)

• Advantages:

• Problem of recall bias is eliminated.

• Advantage of temporality is maintained.

• Economical (Done for rare diseases + whose diagnostic tests are very expensive)

• Greater comparability (as both cases & controls are derived from the original cohort)

• Disadvantage: non diseased persons from whom the controls are selected may not be fully representative of original cohort, due to death or failure to follow up cases

questions.text: A 48-year-old man presented with complaints of a foreign body sensation in nose and frequent spitting of blood-tinged saliva for 6 months duration. On examination, a reddish pedunculated mass studded with whitish spots was seen hanging in nasal cavity. On nasal endoscopy, mass was seen attached along the under surface of left inferior turbinate, which bled on contact. The patient also gave history of taking frequent baths in local ponds. He underwent complete excision of the mass after bipolar cauterisation of the base under local anaesthesis.Postoperative histopathology revealed multiple sporangia in various stages of maturation with dense inflammation.Choose the most appropriate diagnosis
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Rhinosporodiosis
Ref: Read the text below.
Sol:-
Rhinosporidiosis:
Organism: Rhinosporidium seeberi. Distribution: India (Southern parts), Sri lanka.
Sites of Affection:
Most commonly: Nose and Nasopharynx Mulberry shaped polypoidal mass studded with white dots or sporangia on its under surface.
Site: Vestibule (septal area).
Treatment:
Complete excision of the mass with a cutting diathermy and cauterization of its base.
Medical management: Local injection of corticosteroids and courses of dapsone and amphotericin.

questions.text: A case of kidney disease was given repeatedly high doses of frusemide. After one week patient started complaining of decreased hearing. All are true about the disease of the patient except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

It act on the inner hair cells
Ref: Read the text below    
Sol:
•	Furosemide reversibly altered the responses to tones and clicks of the basilar membrane, causing response-magnitude reductions that were largest (up to 61 dB, averaging 25–30 dB) at low stimulus intensities at the characteristic frequency (CF) and small or nonexistent at high intensities and at frequencies far removed from CF. 
•	These results constitute the most definitive demonstration to date that mechanical responses of the basilar membrane are dependent on the normal function of the organ of Corti and strongly implicate the outer hair cells as being responsible for the high sensitivity and frequency selectivity of basilar membrane responses. 
•	A corollary of these findings is that sensorineural hearing deficits in humans due to outer hair cell loss reflect pathologically diminished vibrations of the basilar membrane.

questions.text: Which of the following is associated with MEN 1?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

MEN 1 is characterised by tumours involving the parathyroid glands (95% of cases),pancreas (neuroendocrine tumours, which may be non-functional or functioning; gastrinoma; insulinoma; glucagonoma; VIPoma; Somatostatinoma) (30–80% cases), lung (neuroendocrine carcinoid) (5%), gastrointestinal tract (neuroendocrine carcinoid) (2%) and anterior pituitary tumours (commonly prolactinomas) (30%).MEN 2 is characterised by tumours of the parathyroid and adrenal glands along with medullary thyroid carcinoma. MEN 3 can additionally be associated with mucocutaneous neuromas and Marfanoid habitus. Hemangioblastomas are a feature of von Hippel–Lindau syndrome.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man complaint of reddening of the urine at the time of a recent respiratory infection. The patient is otherwise healthy. The urinalysis shows 2+ protein and dysmorphic RBCs. No WBC or casts are seen. What is the most likely cause of his hematuria?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Dysmorphic erythrocytes and proteinuria suggest a glomerular source of hematuria. Patients with IgA nephropathy often have an exacerbation of their hematuria at the time of upper respiratory illnesses. Although urological cancers, kidney stones, and prostatitis are important causes of hematuria (especially in an older or symptomatic patient), they would not cause dysmorphic erythrocytes or protein in the urine. Acute post streptococcal glomerulonephritis usually occurs a week or two after the sore throat.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man presents with hypertension and peripheral edema. Family history reveals that his father and a brother have kidney disease. Physical examination reveals BP 160/100.Bilateral flank masses are palpable. Urinalysis shows trace protein; his serum creatinine is 3.0 mg/dL. Which will be the most likely cause of mortality in this patient
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

This patient has adult polycystic kidney disease (APCKD), an autosomal dominant condition.
commonest genetic renal disease causing ESRD and often presents with hypertension, hematuria, and large palpable kidneys. The most common cause of mortality in ADPKD is cardiovascular. Malignancy is not seen with increased incidence in ADPKD patients.

questions.text: A patient presented with weakness and frequent headache. On examination BP-110/70 mmHg. There is no dehydration or pedal edema. On laboratory test serum Na is 110 mEq/L. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

SIADH is euvolemic hyponatremia. Volume depletion is unlikely in the absence of dehydration. Cirrhosis and congestive heart failure can cause hyponatremia but would be associated with edema- Hypervolumic hyponatremia.

questions.text: Which of the following is the preferred initial treatment for idiopathic restless leg syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Restless leg syndrome is characterized by ill-defined leg discomfort that occurs in the evening when the patient is reclining or at night when the patient is trying to sleep. The uncomfortable sensation is relieved by movement. Examination is normal. Although most often idiopathic, RLS can be associated with iron-deficiency or renal insufficiency; iron studies (serum iron, total iron-binding capacity and/or ferritin levels) and serum creatinine should be measured. Levodopa-carbidopa is effective but may lead to rebound effects, so direct dopamine agonists (pramipexole, ropinirole) are now preferred. RLS is a sensory, not a motor, syndrome, so muscle stretching exercises or muscle relaxants rarely provide symptom relief.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man is evaluated for 1 year of recurrent episodes of bilateral ear swelling. The ear is painful during these events, and the right ear has become floppy. On examination, the left ear has a beefy red colour and the pinna is tender and swollen; the earlobe appears minimally swollen but is neither red nor tender. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this finding?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Relapsing polychondritis most often presents with recurrent painful swelling of the ear. Episodes of ear involvement may result in floppy ears. Typically the pinna is affected while the earlobe is spared because there is no cartilage in the lobe. 
Cogan syndrome is a rare vasculitis syndrome involving hearing loss, but cartilage inflammation is not a feature. 
Recurrent trauma or irritation is a consideration, it would less likely be bilateral and accompanied by inflammatory findings and a relatively spared earlobe

questions.text: Which of the following in not a feature of Flow phase of systemic effect of burn?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

FLOW / Plateau phase

Hyperdynamic circulation and Hypermetabolic state
Persistent elevation of Urinary Cortisol, Serum cytokines, catecholamines and basal energy requirements, insulin sensitivity and impaired glucose metabolism.
Typically 3 to 4 days after injury - characterized by tachycardia, increased cardiac output, elevated energy expenditure, increased oxygen consumption, and massive proteolysis and lipolysis
GIT: Mucosal atrophy, Changed digestive absorption and increased intestinal permeability. Bowel mucosa atrophy within 12 hours (increased apoptosis). Stress gastritis due to decreased resistance (no increase in acid)- Curling ulcer
 Global depression in immune function and adaptive immunity is downregulated
With burns of more than 20% TBSA, impairment of these immune functions is proportional to burn size
Release of catabolic hormones, such as catecholamines, glucocorticoids, and insulin/glucagon among others
Catecholamine stimulation of beta-adrenergic receptors within the pancreas increases the release of both glucagon and insulin, but concurrent stimulation of alpha-receptors has a greater inhibitory effect on insulin than on glucagon, resulting in a greater net release of glucagon compared with insulin.
The effects of catecholamine-stimulated glucagon release then outweigh the effects of insulin on glucose and fatty acid production and release

questions.text: Which of the following statements are true regarding local anesthetic systemic toxicity?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

CARDIOVASCULAR TOXICITY OF LOCAL ANESTHETICS:
•	MAIN MECHANISM: block of cardiac Na+ channels leading to negative inotropy (hypotension) and arrythmias
•	CVS toxicity is a severe form of toxicity because of slow rate of recovery of blocked sodium channels from bupivacaine (high potency)
•	Arrythmias that can happen are:
•	Prolonged PR interval, wide QRS complexes ultimately leading to sinus bradycardia and cardiac arrest (any rhythm)

TREATMENT
•	Drug of choice is infusion of 20% INTRALIPID solution: bolus dose: 1.5 ml/kg followed by infusion of 0.25 ml \kg\min
•	Mechanism: it increases the rate of recovery of blocked sodium channels by decreasing cardiac bupivacaine concentration.
•	Propofol although contains lipid in it , but is not recommended as a substitute for intralipid because of requirement of large amount of propofol and its hemodynamic effects.
•	No other antiarrhythmic is useful in the management of bupivacaine induced cardiac arrythmias
•	Use of lignocaine is not recommended in arrythmias due to bupivacaine.
•	2 drugs useful are adrenaline and amiodarone as per ACLS guidelines for the management of cardiac arrest
•	Later in severe cases Extra Corporeal Membrane Oxygenation (ECMO) can be used.

Complications of epidural opioids include:

Dose dependant effects: Respiratory Depression, Nausea and Vomiting and Urinary Retention
Dose independent effect: Pruritis
Best answer here will be itching as it won’t be expected to increase due to increase in dose of epidural morphine. Rest all complications will be increased.
Pruritis

Most common and adverse side effect, incidence is greater after intrathecal as compared to systemic administration.
Occurs within first few hours and is localized to the face, thorax and neck.
Mechanism is thought to be due to cephalad migration and interaction with opioid receptors in the trigeminal nucleus.
More common with morphine (70%) than fentanyl(10%).
Naloxone is effective for treatment but may decrease analgesic effects.
Other treatment options include antihistamines, propofol, 5 HT antagonists and NSAIDS.

choices.text: Interosseous (IO) access should not be attempted in children.

questions.text: Which of the following is true concerning alternative routes of drug administration during Cardiopulmonary Resuscitation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

•	Drugs administered via the endotracheal tube should be diluted in 10 mL normal saline to facilitate absorption. 
•	Adequate IV access may not be easy to establish in cardiopulmonary arrest, and alternative routes may need to be considered. 
•	IO is quick and easy to establish in all age groups, and all drugs may be administered via this route. 
•	The endotracheal route has limitations such as administering unknown optimal drug doses and the need to stop CPR while drugs are administered.

questions.text: Identify the correct sequence:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) ROUTINE AIRWAY MANAGEMENT Routine airway management associated with general anesthesia consists of: • Airway assessment • Preparation and equipment check • Patient positioning • Preoxygenation • Induction agent • Bag and mask ventilation (BMV) • Muscle relaxant • Intubation (if indicated) • Confirmation of endotracheal tube placement • Intraoperative management and troubleshooting • Extubation AIRWAY ASSESSMENT Airway assessment is the first step in successful airway management. Important points are: • Mouth opening: an incisor distance of 3 cm or greater is desirable in an adult. • Mallampati classification: a frequently performed test that examines the size of the tongue in relation to the oral cavity. The greater the tongue obstructs the view of the pharyngeal structures, the more difficult intubation may be ■ Class I: the entire palatal arch, including the bilateral faucial pillars, are visible down to their bases. ■ Class II: the upper part of the faucial pillars and most of the uvula are visible. ■ Class III: only the soft and hard palates are visible. ■ Class IV: only the hard palate is visible. • Thyromental distance: the distance between the mentum and the superior thyroid notch. A distance greater than 3 fingerbreadths is desirable. • Neck circumference: a neck circumference of greater than 27 in is suggestive of difficulties in visualization of the glottic opening. EQUIPMENT Preparation is mandatory for all airway management scenarios. The following equipment is routinely needed in airway management situations: • An oxygen source • BMV capability • Laryngoscopes (direct and video) • Several endotracheal tubes of different sizes • Other (not endotracheal tube) airway devices (eg, oral, nasal airways) • Suction • Oximetry and CO2 detection • Stethoscope • Tape • Blood pressure and electrocardiography (ECG) monitors • Intravenous access POSITIONING • When manipulating the airway, correct patient positioning is required. • Relative alignment of the oral and pharyngeal axes is achieved by having the patient in the “sniffing” position. • When cervical spine pathology is suspected, the head must be kept in a neutral position during all airway manipulations. • In-line stabilization of the neck must be maintained during airway management in these patients • Patients with morbid obesity should be positioned on a 30° upward ramp, as the functional residual capacity (FRC) of obese patients deteriorates in the supine position, leading to more rapid deoxygenation should ventilation be impaired. PREOXYGENATION • When possible, preoxygenation with face mask oxygen should precede all airway management interventions. • Oxygen is delivered by mask for several minutes prior to anesthetic induction. In this way, the functional residual capacity, the patient’s oxygen reserve, is purged of nitrogen. BAG AND MASK VENTILATION • Bag and mask ventilation (BMV) is the first step in airway management in most situations, with the exception of patients undergoing rapid sequence intubation. • BMV precedes attempts at intubation to oxygenate the patient ENDOTRACHEAL INTUBATION • Endotracheal intubation is employed both for the conduct of general anesthesia and to facilitate the ventilator management of the critically ill. • Most common intubation is oro tracheal intubation by performing direct laryngoscopy using a curved blade laryngoscope ( macintosh blade) • The laryngoscope is held in left hand and inserted from right angle of mouth and the tip of the blade is inserted till the vallecula and then lifted from the base of epiglottis to visualize the vocal cords.

questions.text:
Match the following clinical conditions with their appropriate capnography waveforms:

1: Esophageal intubation
2: Bronchospasm
3: Exhausted CO2 absorber from closed circuit
4: Return of spontaneous circulation during CPR
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

•	End-tidal co2 monitoring forms part of universal monitoring for anaesthesia and should also be used for all intubations and transfers in icu, emergency departments and elsewhere. 
•	Capnography measures and graphically displays co2 partial pressure over time.
•	The presence or absence of co2, the value of its partial pressure and the shape of the waveform can give valuable information for the diagnosis of many condition
•	A sloping upstroke ( SHARK FIN ) on the capnograph suggests severe asthma or copd.
•	Oesophageal intubation can be ruled out by capnography, but not an endobronchial intubation.
•	Pulmonary emboli cause v/q mismatch and reduce cardiac output, thus reducing end-tidal co2.
•	Effective cpr leads to increased co2 delivery to the lungs and hence may be monitored with capnography.

questions.text: A person who laughs one minute and cries the next without any clear stimulus is said to have –
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Labile affect
Lability  of  affect  is  found  in  many  conditions.  It  is  defined  as  rapid  and abrupt  changes  in  emotion  largely  unrelated  to  external  stimuli.  These shifts  occur  without  warning.  It  is  found  in  some  people  with  no  psychiatric disorder.  For  example,  those  who  are  very  soft-hearted  may  be  easily  moved to  tears.  Those  with  personality  disorder  of  the  borderline  type  may  also exhibit  lability  of  affect.  However,  it  is  most common in mixed affective states (dysphoric  mania)  and  in  mania  where  short  bursts  of  weeping  are  present. It  may  also  be  a  feature  in  organic  brain  disease  following  damage  to  the frontal  lobe  or  following  cerebrovascular  accidents.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a disorder of form of thought?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Thought block

questions.solution:

It is used for pre-mature ejaculation

questions.text: Healthy thinking includes all except-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Clarity
Schneider  suggested  there  were  three  features  of  healthy  thinking: 
constancy:  this  is  characteristic  of  a  completed  thought  that  does not  change  in  content  unless  and  until  it  is  superseded  by  another consciously-derived  thought 

organisation:  the  contents  of  thought  are  related  to  each  other  in consciousness  and  do  not  blend  with  each  other,  but  are  separated  in an  organised  way 

continuity:  there  is  a  continuity  of  the  sense  continuum,  so  that even  the  most  heterogenous  subsidiary  thoughts,  sudden  ideas  or observations  that  emerge  are  arranged  in  order  in  the  whole  content of  consciousness

questions.text: Death of a patient due to extreme anxiety of receding penis in body is called as
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Koro syndrome
Koro  is  an  anxiety-related syndrome  centred  on  the  idea  that  the  penis  is shrinking  into  the  abdomen  and  that  this  will be  followed  by  death.
Koro  or  the  belief  that  the  penis  is  shrinking  and  will  retract  into  the abdomen  and  cause  death  is  found  in  South-East  Asia  and  is  thought  to  be due  to  a  faulty  understanding  of  anatomy.  The  diagnostic  equivalent  is probably  anxiety  disorder.

questions.text: A 17 years old girl had come with history of absence of menarche. Her height is 170cm. breast development is at TANNER stage 4 while axillary and pubic hair development is at TANNER 1. Which of the following should be the next step in investigations?

questions.text: A 32 years old, multiparous patient has history of post-coital bleeding since last 3 months. Her menses are regular and normal. Her general examination is within normal limits but on per speculum examination, it was found that there is an ulcerative lesion on the anterior lip of cervix. Which of the following is suitable investigation in this case?

questions.text: A 26 years old nulliparous patient has PCOS since last 7 years. She has irregular menses with oligomenorrhoea. She has hirsutism and her neck has developed hyperpigmented velvety appearance. She is unable to conceive since last 2 years. Which of the following drugs is not suitable in the treatment of this patient?

Combined OC pills

Combined OC pills will be suitable for those patients who is not planning for pregnancy. In this case, the patient wants to conceive and hence ovulation induction agents are used.

questions.text: A new born baby was born with the following external genitalia. Which of the following is not a likely cause in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Swyer’s syndrome

Ambiguous genitalia are not possible in SWYER syndrome. Swyer syndrome is a condition where there is a defect in SRY gene. There will be gonadal dysgenesis and the external genitalia will have female phenotype.

Letrozole is used in Mc-Cune Albright syndrome. It reduces the production of estrogen. Leuprolide is a GnRH agonist. It is given in continuous form to suppress the HPO axis. Corticosteroids are given in congenital adrenal hyperplasia. COC pills are not given in precocious puberty.

questions.text: A second para, whose first pregnancy had ended in an uncomplicated lower segment caesarean section, is admitted at a POA of 42 weeks. The fetus is in the cephalic presentation. Post term pregnancy with previous LSCS must be subjected to LSCS. VBAC will result in an unfavorable obstetric outcome like failure of induction, scar-rupture, fetal distress etc.

questions.text: A woman is admitted at 30 weeks of gestation following a sudden episode of antepartum hemorrhage of approximately 300 cc. The bleeding has ceased on admission. She is not pale, blood pressure is 120/80 mmHg and the pulse rate is 76 beats per minute. The uterus is soft and non-tender. The fetus is in breech presentation. questions.text: A primigravida who is admitted to the antenatal ward at 35 weeks is found to have a blood pressure of 160/110 mmHg. Her urine does not contain albumin. Which one of the following drugs should not be used in her management?

Furosemide is a diuretic. It will reduce the intra vascular volume which is already reduced due to pre-eclampsia. It will also cause utero placental insufficiency.

questions.text: A primipara complains of colicky lower abdominal pain at a period of amenorrhoea of 31 weeks. The fetus is in cephalic presentation. She is getting 2 uterine contraction per 10 minutes. On speculum examination, the approximate cervical dilatation is 2 cm. The membranes are intact. The fetal heart rate is 140 beats per minute. questions.text: A woman, who had a normal delivery 3 days ago, complains of lower abdominal pain, fever and offensive vaginal discharge. Her temperature is 39°C, pulse rate is 130 beats per minute and the blood pressure is 100/70mm Hg. What is the most important next step in the management?

This is a case of puerperal sepsis. The drug of choice in this case is CLINDAMYCIN and GENTAMICIN. If enterococcal infection is seen then we need to add AMPICILLIN.

questions.text: A woman with mitral stenosis is in the first stage of labour. The cervical dilatation is 4 cm and she is getting 2 uterine contractions per 10 minutes. She is in New York Heart Association Grade 2. Her ejection fraction is 60%. The fetal heart rate is 150 beats per minute. What is the most appropriate method of analgesia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Epidural analgesia.

Ideal analgesia for a case of heart disease in pregnancy is epidural analgesia. It provides excellent pain relief during labour. It must not be given in a case of hypotension.

questions.text: A 30-year-old second para, who has been diagnosed to have antiphospholipid syndrome, attends the antenatal clinic at a POA of 6 weeks. She has had early onset severe pre-eclampsia during the previous pregnancy. A live healthy baby was delivered by LSCS at 33 weeks. This was followed by three spontaneous abortion at 9 weeks. What is the best management option for her?

APLA syndrome is best treated by ASPIRIN and HEPARIN combination. LMWH heparin is much better than unfractionated heparin.

questions.text: Which one of the following is not seen in molar pregnancy?

questions.text: A 63 years old, post-menopausal patient underwent Type 3 hysterectomy for carcinoma of cervix stage 1B1. Histopathology of the specimen revealed that the cancer was spread till the base of uterus. What is the next line of management?

No further treatment

Presence of involvement of uterus in a case of cervical cancer does not change the staging and the mode of treatment. So, no further treatment is required in this case.

questions.text: A patient came to the emergency with sharp, stabbing pain in the chest. An X-ray was taken. Identify the condition.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Pneumothorax
Pneumothorax refers to the presence of gas in the pleural space. When this collection of gas is constantly enlarging with resulting compression of mediastinal structures, it can be life-threatening and is known as a tension pneumothorax (if no tension is present, it is a simple pneumothorax).
Features of Pneumothorax on CXR:
• Visible visceral pleural edge is seen as a very thin, sharp white line
• No lung markings are seen peripheral to this line
• Peripheral space is radiolucent compared to the adjacent lung
• Lung may completely collapse
• Mediastinum should not shift away from the pneumothorax unless a tension pneumothorax is present
• Subcutaneous emphysema

questions.text: A 35-year-old female presents with thunderclap head-ache. What is the likely diagnosis based on image?

SAH
CT head shows blood in Sylvian fissure and Basal cisterns which is classical presentation of subarachnoid hemorrhage.
Another key word to be picked up is "Thunderclap headache" or "Worst headache of my life".

questions.text: Identify the pattern seen in Barium enema shown here.
questions.solution:

Saw tooth sign
The image depicts a barium enema showing serrated edges known as saw tooth pattern. This occurs in diverticulosis. This condition mainly affects the sigmoid colon which happens to be the narrowest part of colon.

questions.text:
An unsupervised 2-year-old boy is found by his parents in the family garage near an open bottle of an unknown liquid. He is minimally responsive and is transported to the emergency department by ambulance. On physical examination, he has labored respiratory effort with diffuse wheezing and is somnolent. An arterial blood gas measurement with electrolytes is obtained, and the data are shown:
Laboratory test
pH 6.83
PCO2 47 mmHg
PO2 100 mm Hg
Sodium 142 mEq/L (142 mmol/L)
Chloride 106 mEq/L (106 mmol/L)
Bicarbonate 6 mEq/L (6 mmol/L)
Of the following, the substance MOST likely ingested by the boy is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

The laboratory data for the boy in the vignette reveal a metabolic acidosis. In addition, a significant increase is seen in the anion gap, which is 30 mEq/L. Of the answer choices, the ingestion most likely to cause an increased anion gap metabolic acidosis is ethanol. Ethanol is the main form of alcohol in grain alcohol, which is used in common libations such as beer, wine, vodka, gin, moonshine, and other spirits. Although the ingestion of ethanol itself does not necessarily generate a metabolic acidosis, ethanol can cause an increase in both lactic acid and ketoacids production and thus produce an anion gap acidosis as a result of the byproducts of metabolism. Ethanol also causes reduced hepatic gluconeogenesis, decreased insulin secretion, increased lipolysis, impaired fatty acid oxidation, and subsequent ketogenesis, leading to an elevated anion gap metabolic acidosis.

choices.text: Diphenhydramine, famotidine, and a corticosteroid orally

questions.text:
A 4-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department by her parents with a rash and facial swelling. Her mother reports that they were at a family cookout when the girl was stung on the right arm by a bee. Within minutes she developed swelling, pain, and a raised, diffuse, red/ itchy rash. Her mother noted swelling of her lips and eyes. Soon after, the girl developed difficulty breathing and had nonbloody, nonbilious emesis once. No medications were given prior to her arrival. Her vital signs are a temperature of 37.6 º C, heart rate of 130 beats/min, respiratory rate 34 breaths/min, and blood pressure of 105/72 mm Hg. Her weight is 22 kg. She appears anxious and has clear rhinorrhea; periorbital edema; tachypnea with expiratory wheezes bilaterally; tachycardia; and multiple raised, erythematous lesions on her arms and trunk.
Of the following, the BEST next step in the management of this child is administration of
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

The girl in the vignette has anaphylaxis from a bee sting (Hymenoptera family). Acute allergic reactions can range from mild to severe. Anaphylaxis is the sudden, life-threatening, IgE-mediated, systemic reaction to an allergen, which may be known or unknown. Anaphylaxis has been defined as an acute reaction that involves 2 or more organ systems (e.g., skin, gastrointestinal, cardiovascular, respiratory) after exposure to an allergen. The definition has been expanded to include the isolated finding of hypotension after exposure to an allergen. Symptoms of anaphylaxis may include rash, flushing, pruritus, rhinorrhea, stridor, cough, wheeze, difficulty breathing, abdominal pain, diarrhea, vomiting, dizziness, syncope, and hypotension. Approximately 10% of children with anaphylaxis do not have cutaneous involvement.
First-line treatment of anaphylaxis is the immediate administration of 0.01 mg/kg of 1:1,000 concentration of intramuscular epinephrine. Intramuscular administration is preferred over subcutaneous due to more efficient absorption, Delayed administration of epinephrine has been associated with fatal outcomes.

questions.text: A full-term female neonate is seen in the neonatal intensive care unit for lumbar myelomeningocele. The pregnancy was otherwise uneventful. The remainder of the physical examination findings are normal. Family history is noncontributory. Of the following, the MOST likely inheritance pattern for the neonate's examination
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

The neonate in the vignette has a neural tube defect (NTD). Neural tube defects exhibit a multifactorial inheritance pattern, which involves the interaction of gene(s) contributed from both sides of the family and the environment. Common multifactorial conditions seen in children include NTDs, cleft lip and palate, and pyloric stenosis.

questions.text:
A previously healthy, 3-week-old girl, born at term, is admitted to the pediatric ward for fever of 38.9 °C. The neonate has been sleepy and not feeding well since the day prior to admission. Her temperature is 37.7 º C (after 1 dose of acetaminophen), heart rate is 180 beats/min, respiratory rate is 40 breaths/min, and oxygen saturation by pulse oximetry is 97% in room air. Her anterior fontanelle is bulging, capillary refill time is 4 seconds, and she is sleepy but arousable. Cardiac and respiratory examination findings are normal.
A complete evaluation for sepsis is initiated, and appropriate antibiotic therapy is administered. Results of a complete blood count and basic metabolic panel are normal. Bacterial culture from the cerebrospinal fluid is positive the following day for Streptococcus pneumoniae. After 72 hours, blood and urine culture results are negative.
Of the following, this child should MOST likely be evaluated for
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

The neonate in the vignette has bacterial meningitis from Streptococcus pneumoniae. Up to 35% of children with meningitis from S pneumoniae will develop hearing loss. All children with bacterial meningitis should undergo evaluation for hearing loss at the time of diagnosis with repeat evaluation at 4 to 8 weeks, 6 months, and 12 months after discharge.

questions.text: What is the most common cause of neonatal meningitis in children all over the world?

Group B strept
